name: Phoenix

faqs.q: What fees apply when I pay over Lightning?
faqs.a: Phoenix charges 0.4% plus 4 sat for every Lightning payment you send.

faqs.q: What happens if I lack inbound liquidity when receiving?
faqs.a: Phoenix may open or splice a channel and charge 1% of the amount plus the mining fee when incoming liquidity is insufficient.

faqs.q: How private are Phoenix payments today?
faqs.a: ACINQ sees the destination and amount of your payments for now, although privacy upgrades are planned.

faqs.q: How do on-chain deposits work in Phoenix?
faqs.a: Phoenix gives you a Bitcoin address; after three confirmations the app swaps the funds to Lightning if fees are below your limit.

faqs.q: How can I restore Phoenix after losing my phone?
faqs.a: Install Phoenix, choose Restore my wallet, enter the 12-word seed, and let channels resync; Android history will not migrate.

supported_network: Lightning only, but you can receive and send on-chain using swaps

WW.text: Option to connect your own node
High on-chain fees for channel creation

description:
Phoenix is designed to provide a simple, self-custodial experience for fast, low-cost Lightning transactions directly on mobile devices, emphasizing ease of use for beginners.

Phoenix runs a native Lightning node on the user's device, connecting to ACINQ's node for automated channel management, eliminating the need for swaps and reducing fees for direct Lightning payments. Additionally, Phoenix allows connections to a user's own Bitcoin node for enhanced privacy.

For beginners, Phoenix's intuitive UI, low-cost Lightning transactions, and self-custodial design make it ideal for those starting with Bitcoin, though channel size limitations may require occasional fee adjustments for frequent receivers. Compared to Breez's merchant-centric features or Aqua's Liquid-focused versatility, Phoenix excels in delivering a straightforward, cost-effective Lightning experience with robust privacy options.

tl_dr.best_for: Mobile-first Lightning payments with self-custody and automated channel care.
tl_dr.consider_if: You expect to receive euro Lightning tips without running your own node.
tl_dr.not_ideal_when: You need desktop access or stronger payment privacy.

steps.title: 1. Install and secure your wallet
actions: Install Phoenix from App Store or Google Play
Write down your 12-word seed on paper and store it away from your device
Enable biometric lock on your phone
steps.gotcha: Never upload the seed to email, chat apps, or cloud drives.

steps.title: 2. Receive your first sats
actions: Tap Receive to generate a Lightning invoice
Share the QR code with your payer
Keep the app awake until payment settles
steps.gotcha: First payment may open a channel and charge ~1,000 sat plus current mining fees if the network is busy.

steps.title: 3. Make a payment
actions: Tap Send and scan or paste a Lightning invoice
Review the amount and memo, then confirm
Wait for the success banner (Phoenix retries automatically if needed)
steps.gotcha: For large invoices, adjust the maximum acceptable fee in Settings → Channel management before sending.

fees_scenarios.title: Pay someone
fees_scenarios.how_to_minimize: Avoid lots of tiny payments when the network is busy.
fees_scenarios.learn_more: Every outgoing Lightning payment includes this fee. The 4 sat is Phoenix's service charge, and the 0.4% covers routing through the Lightning network.

fees_scenarios.title: First time you receive
fees_scenarios.cost_today: ≈1,000 sat channel creation + current mining fee
fees_scenarios.what_happens: Phoenix opens a Lightning channel so you can receive payments.
fees_scenarios.how_to_minimize: Wait for low on-chain fees (check mempool.space); receive when network is quiet.
fees_scenarios.learn_more: Your first Lightning receive triggers channel creation. Phoenix must commit an on-chain transaction to open the channel, which incurs the current Bitcoin mining fee plus a 1,000 sat setup charge.

fees_scenarios.title: Inbound Liquidity (Splicing)
fees_scenarios.what_happens: Phoenix resizes your channel to accept more sats than current capacity allows.
fees_scenarios.how_to_minimize: Consolidate into fewer, larger receives; spend down balance before receiving large amounts.
fees_scenarios.learn_more: When incoming payment exceeds available channel capacity, Phoenix performs a splice-in operation. This on-chain transaction increases your channel size and costs 1% of the received amount plus current mining fees.

fees_faq.q: Does Phoenix charge me every time I receive?
fees_faq.a: Not always. Once your channel exists and has room, small Lightning receives can be free aside from routing.

fees_faq.q: When will Phoenix open or resize a channel?
fees_faq.a: On your first Lightning receive or when more inbound capacity is needed.

fees_faq.q: How do I avoid the 1% splice fee?
fees_faq.a: Consolidate larger receives and avoid on-chain fee spikes.

key_terms.definition: Creates your first Lightning channel so you can receive.
Increases channel capacity to take larger receives.
On-chain fee paid when opening/resizing; varies with network demand.

data_flows: Phoenix connects to ACINQ's Lightning node to route payments. Today, ACINQ can see who you pay and the amount needed to deliver your payment.
On-chain transactions are public by design; reuse of addresses can link activity.
Use your own Electrum server (Settings) to limit what third parties learn about your addresses and balances.
Lightning peers still observe timing/amount metadata needed for routing.
privacy.data_flows_do: Connect your own Electrum server if privacy matters.
privacy.data_flows_dont: Assume Lightning is fully private. Some metadata still leaks via peers.
recovery: Your 12-word seed lives only on your phone. ACINQ can't recover it for you. Channel states are encrypted and synced so they can be restored.
Standard restore: install Phoenix → Restore my wallet → enter seed → keep the phone online while channels resync.
If Phoenix/ACINQ is unavailable: Settings → Danger zone → Force close channels. After ~720 blocks, funds appear in the Final wallet; then sweep on-chain.
privacy.recovery_do: Store your seed offline and test a small restore when convenient.
privacy.recovery_dont: Run Phoenix on two phones at the same time.
region: App-store availability and funding options vary by country—check your local listing and on-ramp.
Install only from the official developer (ACINQ) on Apple App Store or Google Play.
Avoid third-party APKs; they're a common source of malware.

micro_faqs.q: Does Phoenix work with my own node or Electrum?
micro_faqs.a: Yes. Connect your Electrum server to improve privacy; Lightning peers still see routing metadata.

micro_faqs.q: Can ACINQ recover my wallet if I lose the seed?
micro_faqs.a: No. The seed never leaves your device.
Use Force close; funds appear in the Final wallet after confirmations, then sweep.

compat_explainers.why: Phoenix natively routes payments over Lightning with low fees (0.4% + 4 sat).

Review the amount and routing fee
compat_explainers.gotcha: For very large payments, adjust the maximum fee cap in Settings → Channel management before sending.

compat_explainers.why: You can send to regular Bitcoin addresses by closing channels or using swap-out.
try: Paste a Bitcoin address in the Send field
Phoenix routes via on-chain (swap-out or channel close)
Confirm and wait for blockchain confirmations
compat_explainers.gotcha: On-chain sends incur mining fees that vary with network congestion. Check mempool.space first.

migration.title: Restore Phoenix on a new phone
migration.choose: When you get a new device and want to keep using Phoenix.
steps: Install Phoenix on the new phone and verify it's the official app from ACINQ.
Choose Restore my wallet, enter your 12-word seed, and wait for channels to resync.
Remove Phoenix from the old device once the new install works; never run both simultaneously.
migration.tips: Don't run Phoenix on two phones at the same time: channel states will conflict. Keep the new device online during resync; it may take a few minutes.
migration.gotcha: Android transaction history won't migrate; only your balance and channels restore.

migration.title: Another wallet → to Phoenix
migration.choose: When you want to start using Phoenix but have funds in a different Lightning wallet.
steps: Install Phoenix and complete the initial setup to generate your wallet and first channel.
In Phoenix, tap Receive and generate a Lightning invoice for the amount you want to transfer.
In your old wallet, send the Lightning payment to the Phoenix invoice. Start with a small test (~10,000 sats) first.
migration.tips: Always test with a small amount first. Phoenix will automatically open a channel if needed (costs ~1,000 sat + mining fee). Keep both apps open during the transfer.
migration.gotcha: Your old wallet's channel balance can't be transferred directly—you must send payments to Phoenix, which takes a minute or two.

migration.title: Phoenix → to on-chain wallet
migration.choose: When you want to move Bitcoin for long-term storage.
steps: Open Phoenix, go to Settings > Close channels, and confirm cooperative close (cheapest way to exit).
Wait for closing transactions to confirm (1–6 blocks); funds appear in Phoenix's Final wallet view.
Sweep coins to your preferred on-chain wallet once confirmed.
migration.tips: Prefer cooperative close over force close; it's faster and cheaper. Check current fees before closing; wait for low-fee periods to save sats.
migration.gotcha: Forced close can take up to 5 days and costs more. Only use if ACINQ is offline.

migration.title: Phoenix → to another Lightning wallet
migration.choose: When you want to try a different Lightning wallet and move your Phoenix balance.
steps: Install your new wallet and complete its backup process.
Send a small test payment (~10,000 sats) from Phoenix to the new wallet to verify it works.
Close Phoenix channels (Settings > Close channels) and sweep remaining funds once confirmed.
migration.tips: Test first with a small amount (~10,000 sats) to catch issues before moving everything. Verify the new wallet's recovery model matches your security preferences.
